trial_identification.studytitle: Health benefits of fresh pork in overweight but healthy individuals.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Assessing cardiometabolic health benefits (primarily body fat) associated with eating fresh pork in healthy, but overweight participants.
trial_identification.secondaryid: New secondary ID. Please modify. ACTRN12608000190303

conditions.healthcondition: Healthy but overweight volunteers are being studied. The intervention may improve body composition (reducing body fat).

interventions.interventions: Fresh lean pork diet (participants will consume up to 7 serves of pork per week for 6 months), habitual diet (participants who are low pork eaters (less than 1 serve a week) will maintain their regular diet for 6 months.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Percentage body fat using dual x-ray absorptiometry (DEXA)

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: BMI greater than or equal to 25 but otherwise healthy; able to eat pork for 6 months; aged 18-65; eat less than 1 serve of pork per week.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Weight >136kg (DEXA limited); diagnosed diabetes or cardiovascular disease; taking fish oil (>1g/d); females who are pregnant or possibly pregnant (DEXA); smokers.

trial_design.concealment: Contacting the holder of the randomisation schedule who would not be seeing volunteers
trial_design.sequence: Stratified allocation based on age, gender and BMI

fundingsource.fundingaddress: Level 1 Eastick Building, University of Adelaide, Roseworthy Campus. PO Box 466, Willaston, South Australia 5118

ethicsAndSummary.summary:
Studies have shown that high protein diets containing lean cuts of meat can improve a number of cardiovascular disease risk factors, including improved glucose control and insulin sensitivity, increased satiety, reductions in blood cholesterol, risk of type II diabetes, blood pressure and body weight and improved weight control. Lean pork as part of a high protein diet has not been studied.
The aims of our research is to evaluate the health benefits of regular pork consumption by determining the relationship between consumption of pork and markers of cardiovascular and metabolic (cardiometabolic) health which include body composition (% body fat, body weight), blood lipids, blood glucose, arterial compliance, blood pressure and insulin sensitivity.
Hypothesis: -Regular consumption of lean fresh pork will not increase risk factors for cardiovascular disease but may actually improve cardiometabolic health.
